newExamYearQuestionList.questionText: A 35-year-old woman comes in due to episodic dizziness for 2 months.  The patient has had 3 separate episodes of dizziness in which she felt that everything was rapidly spinning around her.  At the same time, her right ear felt full, and she heard a loud "whistling" sound in that ear.  Each of these episodes occurred suddenly, lasted about 2-3 hours, and then resolved completely.  The patient has no symptoms in between the episodes.  She drinks 2 or 3 cups of coffee daily and 2 or 3 glasses of wine during the weekends.  The patient uses combined oral contraceptive pills.  She has a desk job and does not exercise.  BMI is 28 kg/m2.  Physical examination and MRI of the brain show no abnormalities.  An audiogram showed mild to moderate low-frequency sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear.  Which of the following lifestyle modification strategies would have the most immediate effect on improving this patient's dizziness?
newExamYearQuestionList.explanationText:
Ménière disease

Pathophysiology

  • Increased volume &/or pressure of endolymph (endolymphatic hydrops)

Clinical manifestations

  • Discrete episodes lasting 20 min to 24 hr
  • Vertigo (sensation of movement, spinning)
  • Hearing loss (unilateral, low-frequency sensorineural)
  • Tinnitus &/or aural fullness

Work-up

  • Comprehensive audiogram
  • MRI (to rule out other central causes of vertigo)

Treatment

  • Diet & lifestyle modification (eg, ↓ dietary salt, ↓ caffeine & alcohol, ↓ allergy triggers)
  • Maintenance pharmacotherapy (eg, hydrochlorothiazide, betahistine)
  • Pharmacotherapy for acute episodes (eg, vestibular suppressants, antiemetics)

This patient has episodic vertigo with hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness, the classic triad of Ménière disease, a disorder of the inner ear characterized by increased volume and pressure of endolymph (endolymphatic hydrops).

Lifestyle modifications are first-line therapy for Ménière disease and include:

  • Dietary salt restriction (2-3 g maximum per day):  Sodium restriction may reduce endolymphatic fluid, thereby helping reduce endolymphatic hydrops (Choice B).

  • Limitation of caffeine and nicotine:  Vasoconstrictors may reduce blood flow to the inner ear.

  • Limitation of alcohol:  Alcohol may cause fluid shifts that impact the inner ear.

  • Avoidance of allergy triggers:  Both food and environmental allergies seem to trigger attacks in some patients, perhaps due to allergies leading to increased fluid extravasation into the endolymphatic sac.

Improving sleep hygiene and stress management skills may also help.  If lifestyle modifications fail to control symptoms, diuretics (eg, hydrochlorothiazide) and/or vasodilators (eg, betahistine) are often used.  Vestibular suppressants (eg, benzodiazepines) and/or antiemetics (eg, promethazine) can be used during acute attacks.

(Choices A and D)  Weight loss and cardiovascular exercise are helpful for many medical conditions and are often recommended as part of a comprehensive plan for patient wellness.  However, salt restriction, limitation of caffeine and alcohol, and allergy avoidance seem much more effective at specifically reducing symptoms from Ménière disease.

(Choice E)  Some patients with Ménière disease have premenstrual exacerbations due to hormonal effects on fluid composition of the inner ear.  In these patients, combined oral contraceptive pills can blunt hormonal fluctuations, which may help decrease the frequency and severity of episodes.

Educational objective:
Ménière disease presents with episodic vertigo with hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness.  Lifestyle modifications including a low-salt diet, limitation of alcohol and caffeine, and avoidance of allergy triggers are first-line therapy.
newExamYearQuestionList.subject: Family medicine

answerChoiceList.choice: Performing cardiovascular exercises 3 times per week
Using an alternate form of contraception

newExamYearQuestionList.questionText: A 35-year-old woman is evaluated due to episodic dizziness for 2 months.  The patient has had 3 separate episodes of dizziness in which she felt that everything was rapidly spinning around her.  At the same time, her right ear felt full, and she heard a loud "whistling" sound in that ear.  Each of these episodes occurred suddenly, lasted about 2-3 hours, and then resolved completely.  The patient has no symptoms in between the episodes.  She drinks 2 or 3 cups of coffee daily and 2 or 3 glasses of wine during the weekends.  The patient uses combined oral contraceptive pills.  She has a desk job and does not exercise.  BMI is 28 kg/m2.  Physical examination and MRI of the brain show no abnormalities.  An audiogram showed mild to moderate low-frequency sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear.  Which of the following lifestyle modification strategies would have the most immediate effect on improving this patient's dizziness?
newExamYearQuestionList.explanationText:
This patient has episodic vertigo with hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness, the classic triad of Ménière disease, a disorder of the inner ear characterized by increased volume and pressure of endolymph (endolymphatic hydrops).

Lifestyle modifications are first-line therapy for Ménière disease and include:

  • Dietary salt restriction (2-3 g maximum per day):  Sodium restriction may reduce endolymphatic fluid, thereby helping reduce endolymphatic hydrops (Choice B).

  • Limitation of caffeine and nicotine:  Vasoconstrictors may reduce blood flow to the inner ear.

  • Limitation of alcohol:  Alcohol may cause fluid shifts that impact the inner ear.

  • Avoidance of allergy triggers:  Both food and environmental allergies seem to trigger attacks in some patients, perhaps due to allergies leading to increased fluid extravasation into the endolymphatic sac.

Improving sleep hygiene and stress management skills may also help.  If lifestyle modifications fail to control symptoms, diuretics (eg, hydrochlorothiazide) and/or vasodilators (eg, betahistine) are often used.  Vestibular suppressants (eg, benzodiazepines) and/or antiemetics (eg, promethazine) can be used during acute attacks.

(Choices A and D)  Weight loss and cardiovascular exercise are helpful for many medical conditions and are often recommended as part of a comprehensive plan for patient wellness.  However, salt restriction, limitation of caffeine and alcohol, and allergy avoidance seem much more effective at specifically reducing symptoms from Ménière disease.

(Choice E)  Some patients with Ménière disease have premenstrual exacerbations due to hormonal effects on fluid composition of the inner ear.  In these patients, combined oral contraceptive pills can blunt hormonal fluctuations, which may help decrease the frequency and severity of episodes.

Educational objective:
Ménière disease presents with episodic vertigo with hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness.  Lifestyle modifications including a low-salt diet, limitation of alcohol and caffeine, and avoidance of allergy triggers are first-line therapy.

newExamYearQuestionList.questionText: A 50-year-old man comes for evaluation of a white patch on the buccal mucosa.  The lesion has been present for 2 months.  The patient reports no pain, itching, or bleeding.  He has no chronic medical conditions and takes no medications.  The patient has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes per day for 30 years.  The oral lesion is shown in the exhibit.  The lesion cannot be wiped off with gauze.  Dental examination reveals crowns on multiple teeth, but no sharp margins are evident on palpation of these crowns.  There is no regional lymphadenopathy.  Which of the following is the best next step in management?
newExamYearQuestionList.explanationText:
Oral leukoplakia

Risk factors

  • Tobacco & alcohol use

Clinical features

  • Painless white mucosal patch
  • Cannot be wiped off

Increased risk of cancer

  • Nonhomogeneous gross appearance
  • Large size (>4 cm)
  • Dysplasia seen on biopsy

Management

  • Biopsy (at diagnosis & if appearance changes)
  • Risk factor modification (eg, tobacco cessation)
  • Close monitoring
  • ± Surgical excision

This patient has a persistent, white mucosal lesion (ie, leukoplakia) on the buccal mucosa that cannot be wiped off with gauze.  Although leukoplakia is often a benign condition, it may represent a premalignant (eg, dysplasia) or malignant (eg, squamous cell carcinoma) lesion; therefore, biopsy is required.

Most head and neck cancers arise from squamous epithelial cells that undergo stepwise changes progressing toward carcinoma (ie, hyperplasia → dysplasia → carcinoma in situ → invasive carcinoma).  Premalignant lesions may initially manifest in the oral cavity as hyperplastic or dysplastic white (leukoplakia) or red (erythroplakia) patches.  Because these lesions are at risk of malignant transformation, they require biopsy to rule out cancer and characterize the extent of any premalignant changes.

If biopsy does not show malignancy, patients require counseling regarding risk reduction (eg, tobacco and alcohol cessation), regular examination of the oral cavity, and repeat biopsy if the lesion changes (eg, increased thickness/firmness, color changes, associated adenopathy).  Surgical excision may decrease the risk of malignant transformation and can also be considered.

(Choice B)  If biopsy results are cancerous, CT scan of the face and neck is performed to evaluate for regional metastatic spread to the cervical lymph nodes.  However, CT scan is not needed if biopsy shows benign or premalignant changes; therefore, biopsy should be performed first.

(Choice C)  Glucocorticoids (topical or intralesional) can be used to treat aphthous ulcerations.  In contrast to this patient's lesion, aphthous ulcerations are typically painful and short-lasting, appearing as blisters or ulcerations rather than a white, plaque-like, persistent lesion.

(Choice D)  Repeated trauma from rough-edged crowns, broken teeth, or ill-fitting dentures can cause chronic irritation leading to hyperkeratotic changes and leukoplakia.  However, this patient's dental crowns have no sharp margins; therefore, they are unlikely to be the cause of leukoplakia, and complete removal is not indicated.  In addition, biopsy should be performed now (vs in 6 months) in case any premalignant or malignant changes are present.

(Choice E)  Smoking cessation should be recommended in patients with leukoplakia, whether benign or due to oral cavity carcinoma.  However, biopsy should be performed now; follow-up in 6 months risks delaying diagnosis of possible malignancy.

Educational objective:
Leukoplakia in the oral cavity may represent a premalignant or malignant lesion.  Therefore, leukoplakia requires biopsy.
newExamYearQuestionList.subject: Surgery

answerChoiceList.choice: CT scan of the face and neck
Recommend removal of the dental crowns and follow-up in six months
Recommend smoking cessation and follow-up in six months
